trial_identification.studytitle: The evaluation of Chinese therapeutic food for the treatment of dyslipidemia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients with dyslipidemia, is the selected Chinese therapeutic food (specifically an extrat combining Hawthorn fruit and Chinese kiwi fruit) better than placebo, for regulating abnormal blood lipid levels?

interventions.interventions: Intake of the therapeutic food powder(specifically an extract of Hawthorn fruit and Chinese kiwi fruit), 20g daily, for one month The extracting concentration: raw Hawthorn fruit and raw Chinese kiwi fruit: extract powder=5:1 (It means that one unit of the powder is extracted and concentrated from five units of the raw fruits)
interventions.comparator: Intake of placebo powder(made of wheat germ and food additives) with similar looking and taste of the therapeutic food, 20g daily, for one month

primaryOutcome.outcome: changes of the levels of blood lipids (TC, LDL, HDL, TG) comparing with the levels at baseline
primaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline, 4 and 8 weeks after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: changes of participants' general well-being, comparing with baseline assessment. The questionnaires of 'Short form 36' and 'Chinese medicine diagnostic assessment' will be used.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline, 2, 4 and 8 weeks after intervention commencement

trial_design.concealment: Subjects will be divided into two groups, randomly matched through their initial blood lipid levels and other baseline characteristics. A PhD student will be invited as the third party to label the treatment and placebo powder (both of them will be packed in similar-looking containers), and to assign those treatment or placebo powder (marked as A or B) to match the participantsâ€™ codes and groups in which they are assigned. Only the "third party"will know the information of labels and codes, and will be asked not to reveal relevant information to either researchers or participants.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study aim is to evaluate the efficacy of selected Chinese therapeutic food (an extract combining Hawthorn fruit and Chinese Kiwi fruit) for dyslipidemia treatment. It is the hypothesized that the therapeutic food may have a positive effect on the treatment of dyslipidemia, and that it may improve participants general well-being.
